trans-unit.source: Azure virtual machine backup - Backup | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure virtual machine backup - Backup | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to backup an Azure virtual machine after registration
trans-unit.target: Learn how to backup an Azure virtual machine after registration

trans-unit.source: Backup Azure virtual machines
trans-unit.target: Backup Azure virtual machines

trans-unit.source: This article is the essential guide to backing up Azure virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: This article is the essential guide to backing up Azure virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Before you proceed, ensure that all the [prerequisites](backup-azure-vms-introduction.md#prerequisites) have been met.
trans-unit.target: Before you proceed, ensure that all the [prerequisites](backup-azure-vms-introduction.md#prerequisites) have been met.

trans-unit.source: Backing up Azure virtual machines involves three key steps:
trans-unit.target: Backing up Azure virtual machines involves three key steps:

trans-unit.source: Three steps to backup an Azure virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Three steps to backup an Azure virtual machine

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Virtual machine backup is local.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Virtual machine backup is local.

trans-unit.source: The backup vault from a specified Azure region will not allow you to backup virtual machines from another Azure region.
trans-unit.target: The backup vault from a specified Azure region will not allow you to backup virtual machines from another Azure region.

trans-unit.source: Thus for every Azure region that has VMs that need backup, at least 1 backup vault must be created in that region.
trans-unit.target: Thus for every Azure region that has VMs that need backup, at least 1 backup vault must be created in that region.

trans-unit.source: 1. Discover Azure virtual machines
trans-unit.target: 1. Discover Azure virtual machines

trans-unit.source: The discovery process queries Azure for the list of virtual machines in the subscription, along with additional information like the Cloud Service name and the Region.
trans-unit.target: The discovery process queries Azure for the list of virtual machines in the subscription, along with additional information like the Cloud Service name and the Region.

trans-unit.source: The discovery process should always be run as the first step.
trans-unit.target: The discovery process should always be run as the first step.

trans-unit.source: This is to ensure that any new virtual machines added to the subscription are identified.
trans-unit.target: This is to ensure that any new virtual machines added to the subscription are identified.

trans-unit.source: To trigger the discovery process
trans-unit.target: To trigger the discovery process

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the backup vault, which can be found under **Recovery Services** in the Azure portal, and then click the **Registered Items** tab.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the backup vault, which can be found under **Recovery Services** in the Azure portal, and then click the **Registered Items** tab.

trans-unit.source: Choose the type of workload in the drop-down menu as **Azure Virtual Machine**, and then click the **Select** button.
trans-unit.target: Choose the type of workload in the drop-down menu as **Azure Virtual Machine**, and then click the **Select** button.

trans-unit.source: select workload
trans-unit.target: select workload

trans-unit.source: Click the **DISCOVER** button at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click the **DISCOVER** button at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: ![discover button](./media/backup-azure-vms/discover-button-only.png)
trans-unit.target: ![discover button](./media/backup-azure-vms/discover-button-only.png)

trans-unit.source: The discovery process can run for a few minutes while the virtual machines are being tabulated.
trans-unit.target: The discovery process can run for a few minutes while the virtual machines are being tabulated.

trans-unit.source: A toast notification at the bottom of the screen appears while the discovery process is running.
trans-unit.target: A toast notification at the bottom of the screen appears while the discovery process is running.

trans-unit.source: discover vms
trans-unit.target: discover vms

trans-unit.source: Once the discovery process is complete, a toast notification appears.
trans-unit.target: Once the discovery process is complete, a toast notification appears.

trans-unit.source: discover-done
trans-unit.target: discover-done

trans-unit.source: 2. Register Azure virtual machines
trans-unit.target: 2. Register Azure virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Before a virtual machine can be protected it needs to be registered with the Azure Backup service.
trans-unit.target: Before a virtual machine can be protected it needs to be registered with the Azure Backup service.

trans-unit.source: The primary goal of the Registration process is to associate the virtual machine with the Azure Backup service.
trans-unit.target: The primary goal of the Registration process is to associate the virtual machine with the Azure Backup service.

trans-unit.source: Registration is typically a one-time activity.
trans-unit.target: Registration is typically a one-time activity.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The backup extension is not installed during the Registration step.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The backup extension is not installed during the Registration step.

trans-unit.source: The installation and update of the backup agent is now part of the scheduled backup job.
trans-unit.target: The installation and update of the backup agent is now part of the scheduled backup job.

trans-unit.source: To register virtual machines
trans-unit.target: To register virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the backup vault, which can be found under **Recovery Services** in the Azure portal, and then click the **Registered Items** tab
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the backup vault, which can be found under **Recovery Services** in the Azure portal, and then click the **Registered Items** tab

trans-unit.source: Choose the type of workload in the drop-down menu as **Azure Virtual Machine** and then click the select button.
trans-unit.target: Choose the type of workload in the drop-down menu as **Azure Virtual Machine** and then click the select button.

trans-unit.source: select workload
trans-unit.target: select workload

trans-unit.source: Click the **REGISTER** button at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click the **REGISTER** button at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: ![register button](./media/backup-azure-vms/register-button-only.png)
trans-unit.target: ![register button](./media/backup-azure-vms/register-button-only.png)

trans-unit.source: In the **Register Items** shortcut menu, choose the virtual machines that you would like to register.
trans-unit.target: In the **Register Items** shortcut menu, choose the virtual machines that you would like to register.

trans-unit.source: If there are two or more virtual machines with the same name use the cloud service to distinguish between the virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: If there are two or more virtual machines with the same name use the cloud service to distinguish between the virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: The **Register** operation can be done at scale, which means that multiple virtual machines can be selected at one time to be registered.
trans-unit.target: The **Register** operation can be done at scale, which means that multiple virtual machines can be selected at one time to be registered.

trans-unit.source: This greatly reduces the one-time effort spent in preparing the virtual machine for backup.
trans-unit.target: This greatly reduces the one-time effort spent in preparing the virtual machine for backup.

trans-unit.source: A job is created for each virtual machine that should be registered.
trans-unit.target: A job is created for each virtual machine that should be registered.

trans-unit.source: The toast notification shows the status of this activity.
trans-unit.target: The toast notification shows the status of this activity.

trans-unit.source: Click **View Job** to go to the **Jobs** page.
trans-unit.target: Click **View Job** to go to the **Jobs** page.

trans-unit.source: register job
trans-unit.target: register job

trans-unit.source: The virtual machine also appears in the list of registered items and the status of the registration operation is shown.
trans-unit.target: The virtual machine also appears in the list of registered items and the status of the registration operation is shown.

trans-unit.source: Registering status 1
trans-unit.target: Registering status 1

trans-unit.source: Once the operation is completed, the status in the portal will change to reflect the registered state.
trans-unit.target: Once the operation is completed, the status in the portal will change to reflect the registered state.

trans-unit.source: Registration status 2
trans-unit.target: Registration status 2

trans-unit.source: 3. Protect: Backup Azure virtual machines
trans-unit.target: 3. Protect: Backup Azure virtual machines

trans-unit.source: This step involves setting up a backup and retention policy for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This step involves setting up a backup and retention policy for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: To protect a virtual machine, do the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To protect a virtual machine, do the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the backup vault, which can be found under **Recovery Services** in the Azure portal, and then click the **Registered Items** tab.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the backup vault, which can be found under **Recovery Services** in the Azure portal, and then click the **Registered Items** tab.

trans-unit.source: Choose the type of workload in the drop-down menu as **Azure Virtual Machine**, and then click the **Select** button.
trans-unit.target: Choose the type of workload in the drop-down menu as **Azure Virtual Machine**, and then click the **Select** button.

trans-unit.source: Select workload in portal
trans-unit.target: Select workload in portal

trans-unit.source: Click the **PROTECT** button at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click the **PROTECT** button at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: The **Protect Items** wizard appears.
trans-unit.target: The **Protect Items** wizard appears.

trans-unit.source: The **Protect Items** wizard is where the virtual machines to be protected can be selected.
trans-unit.target: The **Protect Items** wizard is where the virtual machines to be protected can be selected.

trans-unit.source: If there are two or more virtual machines with the same name use the cloud service to distinguish between the virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: If there are two or more virtual machines with the same name use the cloud service to distinguish between the virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: The **Protect** operation can be done at scale, which means that multiple virtual machines can be selected at one time to be registered.
trans-unit.target: The **Protect** operation can be done at scale, which means that multiple virtual machines can be selected at one time to be registered.

trans-unit.source: This greatly reduces the effort spent in protecting the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This greatly reduces the effort spent in protecting the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: In the second screen of the **Protect Items** wizard, choose a backup and retention policy to back up the selected virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: In the second screen of the **Protect Items** wizard, choose a backup and retention policy to back up the selected virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Pick from an existing set of policies or define a new one.
trans-unit.target: Pick from an existing set of policies or define a new one.

trans-unit.source: In each backup vault, you can have multiple backup policies.
trans-unit.target: In each backup vault, you can have multiple backup policies.

trans-unit.source: The policies reflect the details about how the backup should be scheduled and retained.
trans-unit.target: The policies reflect the details about how the backup should be scheduled and retained.

trans-unit.source: For example, one backup policy could be for daily backup at 10:00 P.M., while another backup policy could be for weekly backup at 6:00 A.M.
trans-unit.target: For example, one backup policy could be for daily backup at 10:00 P.M., while another backup policy could be for weekly backup at 6:00 A.M.

trans-unit.source: Multiple backup policies allow flexibility in scheduling backups for your virtual machine infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: Multiple backup policies allow flexibility in scheduling backups for your virtual machine infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Each backup policy can have multiple virtual machines that are associated with the policy.
trans-unit.target: Each backup policy can have multiple virtual machines that are associated with the policy.

trans-unit.source: The virtual machine can be associated with only one policy at any given point in time.
trans-unit.target: The virtual machine can be associated with only one policy at any given point in time.

trans-unit.source: A job is created for each virtual machine to configure the protection policy and to associate the virtual machines to the policy.
trans-unit.target: A job is created for each virtual machine to configure the protection policy and to associate the virtual machines to the policy.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Jobs** tab and choose the right filter to view the list of **Configure Protection** jobs.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Jobs** tab and choose the right filter to view the list of **Configure Protection** jobs.

trans-unit.source: Configure protection job
trans-unit.target: Configure protection job

trans-unit.source: Post-protection activities
trans-unit.target: Post-protection activities

trans-unit.source: Installation of the backup extension
trans-unit.target: Installation of the backup extension

trans-unit.source: The Azure Backup service seamlessly handles the upgrade and patching of the backup extension without requiring any cumbersome user intervention.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Backup service seamlessly handles the upgrade and patching of the backup extension without requiring any cumbersome user intervention.

trans-unit.source: This relieves the user of the �agent management overhead� that is typically associated with backup products.
trans-unit.target: This relieves the user of the �agent management overhead� that is typically associated with backup products.

trans-unit.source: Offline VMs
trans-unit.target: Offline VMs

trans-unit.source: The backup extension is installed if the VM is running.
trans-unit.target: The backup extension is installed if the VM is running.

trans-unit.source: A running VM also provides the greatest chance of getting an application consistent point.
trans-unit.target: A running VM also provides the greatest chance of getting an application consistent point.

trans-unit.source: However, the Azure Backup service will continue to backup the VM even if the VM is turned off and the extension could not be installed (aka Offline VM).
trans-unit.target: However, the Azure Backup service will continue to backup the VM even if the VM is turned off and the extension could not be installed (aka Offline VM).

trans-unit.source: The impact is seen in the consistency - in such a case the recovery point will be *File-system consistent*.
trans-unit.target: The impact is seen in the consistency - in such a case the recovery point will be *File-system consistent*.

trans-unit.source: Initial backup
trans-unit.target: Initial backup

trans-unit.source: Once the virtual machine is protected with a policy, it shows up under the **Protected Items** tab with the status of *Protected - (pending initial backup)*.
trans-unit.target: Once the virtual machine is protected with a policy, it shows up under the **Protected Items** tab with the status of *Protected - (pending initial backup)*.

trans-unit.source: By default, the first scheduled backup is the initial backup.
trans-unit.target: By default, the first scheduled backup is the initial backup.

trans-unit.source: In order to trigger the initial backup immediately after configuring protection, use the **Backup Now** button at the bottom of the Protected Items page.
trans-unit.target: In order to trigger the initial backup immediately after configuring protection, use the **Backup Now** button at the bottom of the Protected Items page.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Backup service creates a backup job for the initial backup operation.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Backup service creates a backup job for the initial backup operation.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Jobs** tab to view the list of jobs.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Jobs** tab to view the list of jobs.

trans-unit.source: As a part of the backup operation, the Azure Backup service issues a command to the backup extension in each virtual machines to flush all writes and take a consistent snapshot.
trans-unit.target: As a part of the backup operation, the Azure Backup service issues a command to the backup extension in each virtual machines to flush all writes and take a consistent snapshot.

trans-unit.source: Backup in progress
trans-unit.target: Backup in progress

trans-unit.source: Once the initial backup is completed, the Protection Status of the virtual machine in the **Protected Items** tab will show as *Protected*.
trans-unit.target: Once the initial backup is completed, the Protection Status of the virtual machine in the **Protected Items** tab will show as *Protected*.

trans-unit.source: Virtual machine is backed up with recovery point
trans-unit.target: Virtual machine is backed up with recovery point

trans-unit.source: Viewing backup status and details
trans-unit.target: Viewing backup status and details

trans-unit.source: Once protected, the virtual machine count also increases in the **Dashboard** page summary.
trans-unit.target: Once protected, the virtual machine count also increases in the **Dashboard** page summary.

trans-unit.source: In addition, the **Dashboard** page shows the number of jobs from the last 24 hours that were successful, have failed, and are still in progress.
trans-unit.target: In addition, the **Dashboard** page shows the number of jobs from the last 24 hours that were successful, have failed, and are still in progress.

trans-unit.source: Clicking on any one category will drill down into that category in the **Jobs** page.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on any one category will drill down into that category in the **Jobs** page.

trans-unit.source: Status of backup in Dashboard page
trans-unit.target: Status of backup in Dashboard page

trans-unit.source: Consistency of recovery points
trans-unit.target: Consistency of recovery points

trans-unit.source: When dealing with backup data, customers worry about the behavior of the VM after it has been restored.
trans-unit.target: When dealing with backup data, customers worry about the behavior of the VM after it has been restored.

trans-unit.source: The typical questions that customers ask are:
trans-unit.target: The typical questions that customers ask are:

trans-unit.source: Will the virtual machine boot up?
trans-unit.target: Will the virtual machine boot up?

trans-unit.source: Will the data be available on the disk (or) is there any data loss?
trans-unit.target: Will the data be available on the disk (or) is there any data loss?

trans-unit.source: Will the application be able to read the data (or) is the data corrupted?
trans-unit.target: Will the application be able to read the data (or) is the data corrupted?

trans-unit.source: Will the data make sense to the application (or) is the data self-consistent when read by the application?
trans-unit.target: Will the data make sense to the application (or) is the data self-consistent when read by the application?

trans-unit.source: The following table explains the types of consistency that are encountered during Azure VM backup and restore.
trans-unit.target: The following table explains the types of consistency that are encountered during Azure VM backup and restore.

trans-unit.source: Consistency
trans-unit.target: Consistency

trans-unit.source: VSS-based
trans-unit.target: VSS-based

trans-unit.source: Explanation and details
trans-unit.target: Explanation and details

trans-unit.source: Application consistency
trans-unit.target: Application consistency

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: This is the ideal place to be for Microsoft workloads as it ensures:
trans-unit.target: This is the ideal place to be for Microsoft workloads as it ensures:

trans-unit.source: That the VM *boots up*.
trans-unit.target: That the VM *boots up*.

trans-unit.source: There is *no corruption*.
trans-unit.target: There is *no corruption*.

trans-unit.source: There is *no data loss*.
trans-unit.target: There is *no data loss*.

trans-unit.source: The data is consistent to the application that uses the data, by involving the application at the time of backup - using VSS.
trans-unit.target: The data is consistent to the application that uses the data, by involving the application at the time of backup - using VSS.

trans-unit.source: The Volume Snapshot Service (VSS) ensures that data is written correctly to the storage.
trans-unit.target: The Volume Snapshot Service (VSS) ensures that data is written correctly to the storage.

trans-unit.source: Most Microsoft workloads have VSS writers that do workload-specific actions related to data consistency.
trans-unit.target: Most Microsoft workloads have VSS writers that do workload-specific actions related to data consistency.

trans-unit.source: For example, Microsoft SQL Server has a VSS writer that ensures the writes to the transaction log file and the database are done correctly.
trans-unit.target: For example, Microsoft SQL Server has a VSS writer that ensures the writes to the transaction log file and the database are done correctly.

trans-unit.source: For Azure VM backup, getting an application consistent recovery point means that the backup extension was able to invoke the VSS workflow and complete *correctly* before the VM snapshot was taken.
trans-unit.target: For Azure VM backup, getting an application consistent recovery point means that the backup extension was able to invoke the VSS workflow and complete *correctly* before the VM snapshot was taken.

trans-unit.source: Naturally, this means that the VSS writers of all the applications in the Azure VM have been invoked as well.
trans-unit.target: Naturally, this means that the VSS writers of all the applications in the Azure VM have been invoked as well.

trans-unit.source: Learn the [basics of VSS](http://blogs.technet.com/b/josebda/archive/2007/10/10/the-basics-of-the-volume-shadow-copy-service-vss.aspx) dive deep into the details of [how it works](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc785914%28v=ws.10%29.aspx).
trans-unit.target: Learn the [basics of VSS](http://blogs.technet.com/b/josebda/archive/2007/10/10/the-basics-of-the-volume-shadow-copy-service-vss.aspx) dive deep into the details of [how it works](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc785914%28v=ws.10%29.aspx).

trans-unit.source: File system consistency
trans-unit.target: File system consistency

trans-unit.source: Yes - for Windows machines
trans-unit.target: Yes - for Windows machines

trans-unit.source: There are two scenarios where the recovery point can be file-system consistent:
trans-unit.target: There are two scenarios where the recovery point can be file-system consistent:

trans-unit.source: Backup of Linux VMs in Azure, since Linux does not have an equivalent platform to VSS.
trans-unit.target: Backup of Linux VMs in Azure, since Linux does not have an equivalent platform to VSS.

trans-unit.source: VSS failure during backup for Windows VMs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: VSS failure during backup for Windows VMs in Azure.

trans-unit.source: In both these cases, the best that can be done is to ensure that:
trans-unit.target: In both these cases, the best that can be done is to ensure that:

trans-unit.source: The VM *boots up*.
trans-unit.target: The VM *boots up*.

trans-unit.source: There is *no corruption*.
trans-unit.target: There is *no corruption*.

trans-unit.source: There is *no data loss*.
trans-unit.target: There is *no data loss*.

trans-unit.source: Applications need to implement their own "fix-up" mechanism on the restored data.
trans-unit.target: Applications need to implement their own "fix-up" mechanism on the restored data.

trans-unit.source: Crash consistency
trans-unit.target: Crash consistency

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: This situation is equivalent to a machine experiencing a "crash" (through either a soft or hard reset).
trans-unit.target: This situation is equivalent to a machine experiencing a "crash" (through either a soft or hard reset).

trans-unit.source: This typically happens when the Azure virtual machine is shut down at the time of backup.
trans-unit.target: This typically happens when the Azure virtual machine is shut down at the time of backup.

trans-unit.source: For Azure virtual machine backup, getting a crash-consistent recovery point means that Azure Backup gives no guarantees around the consistency of the data on the storage medium - either from the perspective of the operating system or from the perspective of the application.
trans-unit.target: For Azure virtual machine backup, getting a crash-consistent recovery point means that Azure Backup gives no guarantees around the consistency of the data on the storage medium - either from the perspective of the operating system or from the perspective of the application.

trans-unit.source: Only data that already exists on the disk at the time of backup is what gets captured and backed up.
trans-unit.target: Only data that already exists on the disk at the time of backup is what gets captured and backed up.

trans-unit.source: While there are no guarantees, in most cases the OS will boot.
trans-unit.target: While there are no guarantees, in most cases the OS will boot.

trans-unit.source: This is typically followed by a disk checking procedure like chkdsk to fix any corruption errors.
trans-unit.target: This is typically followed by a disk checking procedure like chkdsk to fix any corruption errors.

trans-unit.source: Any in-memory data or writes that have not been completely flushed to the disk will be lost.
trans-unit.target: Any in-memory data or writes that have not been completely flushed to the disk will be lost.

trans-unit.source: The application typically follows with its own verification mechanism in case data rollback needs to be done.
trans-unit.target: The application typically follows with its own verification mechanism in case data rollback needs to be done.

trans-unit.source: For Azure VM backup, getting a crash consistent recovery point means that Azure Backup gives no guarantees around the consistency of the data on the storage - either from the OS perspective or the application's perspective.
trans-unit.target: For Azure VM backup, getting a crash consistent recovery point means that Azure Backup gives no guarantees around the consistency of the data on the storage - either from the OS perspective or the application's perspective.

trans-unit.source: This typically happens when the Azure VM is shut down at the time of backup.
trans-unit.target: This typically happens when the Azure VM is shut down at the time of backup.

trans-unit.source: As an example, if the transaction log has entries that are not present in the database, then the database software does a rollback till the data is consistent.
trans-unit.target: As an example, if the transaction log has entries that are not present in the database, then the database software does a rollback till the data is consistent.

trans-unit.source: When dealing with data spread across multiple virtual disks (like spanned volumes), a crash-consistent recovery point provides no guarantees for the correctness of the data.
trans-unit.target: When dealing with data spread across multiple virtual disks (like spanned volumes), a crash-consistent recovery point provides no guarantees for the correctness of the data.

trans-unit.source: Performance and resource utilization
trans-unit.target: Performance and resource utilization

trans-unit.source: Like backup software that is deployed on-premises, backup of VMs in Azure also needs to be planned for capacity and resource utilization.
trans-unit.target: Like backup software that is deployed on-premises, backup of VMs in Azure also needs to be planned for capacity and resource utilization.

trans-unit.source: The [Azure Storage limits](azure-subscription-service-limits.md#storage-limits) will define how VM deployments are structured to get maximum performance with minimum impact to running workloads.
trans-unit.target: The [Azure Storage limits](azure-subscription-service-limits.md#storage-limits) will define how VM deployments are structured to get maximum performance with minimum impact to running workloads.

trans-unit.source: There are two main Azure Storage limits that impact backup performance:
trans-unit.target: There are two main Azure Storage limits that impact backup performance:

trans-unit.source: Max egress per storage account
trans-unit.target: Max egress per storage account

trans-unit.source: Total request rate per storage account
trans-unit.target: Total request rate per storage account

trans-unit.source: When the backup data is copied out of the customer storage account, it counts towards the IOPS and Egress (storage throughput) metrics of the storage account.
trans-unit.target: When the backup data is copied out of the customer storage account, it counts towards the IOPS and Egress (storage throughput) metrics of the storage account.

trans-unit.source: At the same time, the virtual machines are also running and consuming IOPS and throughput.
trans-unit.target: At the same time, the virtual machines are also running and consuming IOPS and throughput.

trans-unit.source: The goal is to ensure that the total traffic - backup and virtual machine - does not exceed the storage account limits.
trans-unit.target: The goal is to ensure that the total traffic - backup and virtual machine - does not exceed the storage account limits.

trans-unit.source: Backup is greedy and tries to consume as many resources as it can, with the aim of completing backup as quickly as possible.
trans-unit.target: Backup is greedy and tries to consume as many resources as it can, with the aim of completing backup as quickly as possible.

trans-unit.source: However, all IO operations are limited by the *Target Throughput for Single Blob* which has a limit of *60MB per second*.
trans-unit.target: However, all IO operations are limited by the *Target Throughput for Single Blob* which has a limit of *60MB per second*.

trans-unit.source: In order to speed up the backup process, the backup of each disk of the VM is attempted *in parallel*.
trans-unit.target: In order to speed up the backup process, the backup of each disk of the VM is attempted *in parallel*.

trans-unit.source: Thus if a VM has 4 disks, then Azure Backup will attempt to backup all 4 disks in parallel.
trans-unit.target: Thus if a VM has 4 disks, then Azure Backup will attempt to backup all 4 disks in parallel.

trans-unit.source: Thus, the single most important factor that determines the backup traffic exiting from a customer storage account is the **number of disks** being backed up from the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Thus, the single most important factor that determines the backup traffic exiting from a customer storage account is the **number of disks** being backed up from the storage account.

trans-unit.source: A secondary factor that impacts the performance is the **backup schedule**.
trans-unit.target: A secondary factor that impacts the performance is the **backup schedule**.

trans-unit.source: If you configure all the VMs to backup at the same time, then the number of disks being backed up *in parallel* will increase - as Azure Backup will attempt to backup as many disks as possible.
trans-unit.target: If you configure all the VMs to backup at the same time, then the number of disks being backed up *in parallel* will increase - as Azure Backup will attempt to backup as many disks as possible.

trans-unit.source: So one way to reduce the backup traffic from a storage account is to ensure that different VMs are backed up at different times of the day, with no overlap.
trans-unit.target: So one way to reduce the backup traffic from a storage account is to ensure that different VMs are backed up at different times of the day, with no overlap.

trans-unit.source: Capacity planning
trans-unit.target: Capacity planning

trans-unit.source: Putting all these factors together means that storage account usage needs to be planned properly.
trans-unit.target: Putting all these factors together means that storage account usage needs to be planned properly.

trans-unit.source: Download the [VM backup capacity planning excel sheet](https://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/Azure-Backup-Storage-a46d7e33) to see the impact of your disk and backup schedule choices.
trans-unit.target: Download the [VM backup capacity planning excel sheet](https://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/Azure-Backup-Storage-a46d7e33) to see the impact of your disk and backup schedule choices.

trans-unit.source: Backup throughput
trans-unit.target: Backup throughput

trans-unit.source: For each disk being backed up, Azure Backup reads the blocks on the disk and stores only the changed data (incremental backup).
trans-unit.target: For each disk being backed up, Azure Backup reads the blocks on the disk and stores only the changed data (incremental backup).

trans-unit.source: The table below shows average throughput values that can be expected from Azure Backup:
trans-unit.target: The table below shows average throughput values that can be expected from Azure Backup:

trans-unit.source: Backup operation
trans-unit.target: Backup operation

trans-unit.source: Best-case Throughput
trans-unit.target: Best-case Throughput

trans-unit.source: Initial backup
trans-unit.target: Initial backup

trans-unit.source: 160 Mbps
trans-unit.target: 160 Mbps

trans-unit.source: Incremental backup (DR)
trans-unit.target: Incremental backup (DR)

trans-unit.source: 640 Mbps
trans-unit.target: 640 Mbps

trans-unit.source: This throughput can drop significantly if there is a lot of dispersed churn on the disk that needs to be backed up
trans-unit.target: This throughput can drop significantly if there is a lot of dispersed churn on the disk that needs to be backed up

trans-unit.source: Using this you can estimate the amount of time that it will take to backup a disk of a given size.
trans-unit.target: Using this you can estimate the amount of time that it will take to backup a disk of a given size.

trans-unit.source: Total VM backup time
trans-unit.target: Total VM backup time

trans-unit.source: While a majority of the time is spent in reading and copying data, there are other operations that contribute to the total time taken to backup a VM:
trans-unit.target: While a majority of the time is spent in reading and copying data, there are other operations that contribute to the total time taken to backup a VM:

trans-unit.source: Time taken to [install or update the backup extension](backup-azure-vms.md#offline-vms)
trans-unit.target: Time taken to [install or update the backup extension](backup-azure-vms.md#offline-vms)

trans-unit.source: Queue wait time : Since the service is processing backups from multiple customers, your backup operation might not start immediately.
trans-unit.target: Queue wait time : Since the service is processing backups from multiple customers, your backup operation might not start immediately.

trans-unit.source: The average wait time for a VM is 15-30 minutes.
trans-unit.target: The average wait time for a VM is 15-30 minutes.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting errors
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting errors

trans-unit.source: Get an exhaustive list of workarounds to the errors that are faced during virtual machine backup: [Troubleshoot virtual machine backup](backup-azure-vms-troubleshoot.md)
trans-unit.target: Get an exhaustive list of workarounds to the errors that are faced during virtual machine backup: [Troubleshoot virtual machine backup](backup-azure-vms-troubleshoot.md)
